| \* [![Gray stone.png](/images/a/a0/Gray_stone.png)](/wiki/File:Gray_stone.png) |                                             |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                           | whetstone                                   |
| Appearance                                                                     | [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") |
| Damage vs. small                                                               | 1d3                                         |
| Damage vs. large                                                               | 1d3                                         |
| To-hit bonus                                                                   | +0                                          |
| Weapon skill                                                                   | [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling")                |
| Size                                                                           | [one-handed](/wiki/One-handed "One-handed") |
| Base price                                                                     | 45 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")            |
| Weight                                                                         | [10](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                 |
| Material                                                                       | [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral")          |

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), a **whetstone** is a [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") that can remove [rust](/wiki/Rust "Rust") and negative [enchantments](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") (up to +0) from an edged [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") or a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) This action requires a source of water ([fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain"), [sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink"), [toilet](/wiki/Toilet "Toilet") or [pool](/wiki/Pool "Pool")). Stand at some water and [apply](/wiki/Apply "Apply") the whetstone.

The whetstone's [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude") determines the chance of success. An [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") will resist the whetstone, lowering this chance.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

| stone                                             | chance of success | with artifact |
| ------------------------------------------------- | ----------------- | ------------- |
| blessed whestone                                  | 1/3               | 1/6           |
| uncursed whetstone                                | 1/4               | 1/7           |
| cursed whestone                                   | 1/6               | 1/9           |
| other [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") | 0                 | 0             |

If you fail, you can try again. If you always fail, your gray stone is not a whetstone. If you succeed, you remove one level of rust; or if there was no rust, you remove one point of negative enchantment.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Restrictions](#Restrictions)
- [2 Time](#Time)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 History](#History)
- [5 References](#References)

## Restrictions

Note that a whetstone cannot remove [corrosion](/wiki/Corrosion "Corrosion").

If you try to use a whetsone with no water other than [potions](/wiki/Potion_of_water "Potion of water") ([BUC](/wiki/BUC "BUC") status does not matter), you get the message, *"Better not waste bottled water on that."*

If your gray stone is not a whetstone, then you will try to sharpen the edge, but your attempt will always fail.

## Time

The number of turns is initially calculated as: 130 + (rnl(13) \* 5)

If cursed, the time is doubled.

On each turn while occupied by sharpening, there are checks to see if you are blind, fumbling, confused, stunned, or hallucinating. If you are free of any of these afflictions, your time remaining is decreased by 2 turns. For each affliction, you get a penalty of 1 turn. As example, if you are confused, your time remaining is reduced by only 1 turn, and if confused and stunned, it is not reduced at all.

## Strategy

These stones are rarely useful. There are many ways to obtain an erodeproof weapon, and most players will have access to one of those long before they find and identify a whetstone. Even for players who luck out and manage to find a whetstone early, they only repair one kind of damage (rust) for one kind of weapon (edged weapons). Furthermore, they require many turns to use, meaning players will likely consume a fair amount of food in using them (especially since their use is easily interrupted by passing monsters).

## History

| **Whetstone**                                                            |                                                                      |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Author                                                                   | Pasi Kallinen                                                        |
| Download                                                                 | [link](http://nhpatchdb.alt.org/~paxed/nethack/nh340-whetstone.diff) |
| [NetHack PatchDB](/wiki/NetHack_Patch_Database "NetHack Patch Database") | [34](http://nhpatchdb.alt.org/?34)                                   |

The whetstone first appeared in a [patch](/wiki/Patch "Patch") for NetHack 3.4.0. Then SLASH'EM 0.0.7E0 included this patch.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [apply.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3, line 2177](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F3/apply.c#line2177 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3/apply.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [apply.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3, line 2088](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F3/apply.c#line2088 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3/apply.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) history.txt in SLASH'EM
